repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Second Phase of the Community
            Development Program Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase of the
            Community Development Program Support Project Cameroon for
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the communal
            development plan (CDP) can be considered as a reference tool
            for planning and dialogue to support local development, but
            its level of ownership by line ministries remains weak.
            Funding and implementation of multi sectoral development
            priorities can improve access to basic social services, but
            mobilization of beneficiaries contributions remains
            insufficient and the demand for economic investments very
            important. The funding allocation system improves resource
            management by municipalities. The citizen control mechanism
            improves communes' governance. Governance remains an
            important challenge for the promotion of local development
            in Cameroon. Decentralization is a very long-term process,
            exceeding project deadlines despite the use of an adaptable
            program loan (APL).

Cameroon - Second Phase of the Community

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Second Phase of the Community
            Development Program Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Phase of the
            Community Development Program Support Project for Cameroon
            is to improve delivery of priority basic services (in
            targeted communes, and extend the ongoing process of
            decentralization to new regions. The main beneficiaries will
            be the communes and communities supported during first phase
            of the Community Development Program Support Project (155)
            plus 167 non covered communes, in which 110 in the five new
            regions. The reallocation is necessary to increase resources
            allocated to category 2 of the financing agreement. Indeed,
            the additional resources will enable the project to cover
            the overdraw done in category two to finance the first
            installments of grants (allocations) to 54 communes in the
            regions of the Northwest, Littoral, South West, Adamaoua and
            Far North, and the updating of Communal Development Plans
            (CDP) of ten former communes of the first phase of Project
            (PNDPI). Indeed, this reallocation of funds has been agreed
            with the government during the mid-term review of the
            project in order to account for changes in the costs of some
            goods and services. The category overdraws was authorized by
            the task team during supervision mission while a formal
            restructuring is being processed. The reallocation among
            categories will be done as follow: SDR 1,400,000 will be
            transferred from category one to category two and SDR
            1,300,000 will be transferred from category three to
            category two. The restructuring does not involve the
            extension of the closing date.

            Community Development Program Support Project :

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Second Phase of the Community
            Development Program Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Phase of the
            Community Development Program Support Project for Cameroon
            is to improve the delivery of specified basic social
            services in targeted communes, and extend the ongoing
            process in support to decentralization to new regions. Since
            its beginning this project implemented the following
            improvements: better access to school for children, better
            access to health services, better access to drinking water,
            new roads have been built.
